body:
Thank you. @mboehm7 , @dusenberrymw 
Ooops! I misunderstood the issue. I'll do it following your comments.
Can an Admin verify this patch?

@gweidner This is awesome!  I ran some tests locally, and the intended use case of executing source statements in a sourced module so that those required modules don't have to be sourced at the top-level script works great.  Thanks!

Also, I found another specific case that we'll want to test for as part of the follow-up [SYSTEMML-631](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SYSTEMML-631): modules that (inadvertently) source themselves, or more generally, circular references.  Otherwise we will end up in an infinite loop.  In general though, if we fix the handling of namespace conflicts and duplicates, this will be fixed anyway.
[Jenkins Build](https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-OnDemand/145/)

1) Sparsity issue: First of all there seems to be an issue with the rand builtin as this matrix should never be represented in dense.
2) Format: Further, I would recommend to always format each number to a fixed length string and always output it in dense (including 0s). By simply using the toString method (as shown in the screenshot) you would get the dense or sparse representation which might be harder to understand for users.
3) This functionality should also automatically obtain a small subset of the matrix in order to avoid that users pull huge matrices into memory.

Thank you both for the review, comments and feedback.  I've push commits to address the following:
1)  Added tests with non-inlined functions at the inner-most imported script.  The corresponding test scripts were adapted from functions.misc.FunctionInliningTest except functions foo1 and foo2 were refactored into separate script files.  Manually checked under Eclipse debugger that StatementBlock.rIsInlineableFunction returned false (at reject control flow blocks).

2) Added verification of no parser error output to console (similar to what was done in functions.misc.SetWorkingDirTest of [SYSTEMML-611](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SYSTEMML-611).  This ensures test fails when parse issues displayed to console.

Also investigated circular references between separate scripts and reproduced stack overflow issue [SYSTEMML-625](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SYSTEMML-625).  Based on stack trace, it hangs in ParseTreeWalker loop before ParserWrapper.createDMLProgram modified in this PR.  I can next look into both issues [SYSTEMML-631], [SYSTEMML-625] as part of separate PR(s).
just a correction wrt to my point (1) - this is fine since the memory estimate for dense is still smaller.

@nakul02 Cool! It's my pain point when work on dml. 
I suggest with simple format parameter like
maxRow=10, maxCol=10, dense=true, decimal=3
Then we can get well format matrix for print.
thanks @akunft @FelixNeutatz @fschueler - that's impressive. I'll look into the details in the next days.

Thanks again @akunft @FelixNeutatz @fschueler @carabolic for contributing this initial Flink backend - this is a really good start. After setting up a recent Flink 1.0.1, I gave it a try on LinearRegDS.dml and a 80GB scenario (10M x 1k, dense w/ binary inputs) in hybrid_flink execution mode. Unfortunately, it was failing during lops construction due to the missing integration of matrix multiply operator selection (in AggBinaryOp). I would recommend to focus on the common distributed operations first: in hybrid execution mode and with moderately large data, we would only run tsmm and mapmm (both compiled from AggBinaryOp) as Flink operations, while all other operations are compiled as pure in-memory CP operations. You have already added all required instructions - that's great, so it would just take some additional wiring in AggBinaryOp and the related lops. 

Furthermore, here are also some additional comments on the actual implementation:

1) APIs and interfaces: Unfortunately, you've put already effort into API extensions. I would recommend to remove the modifications of MLOutput and MLContext because MLOutput is not maintained and MLContext is about to get a major refactoring. Let's use the command line interface for now and extend the APIs once the backend is ready.

2) Isolation of Flink dependencies: We need to be very careful about introducing Flink API dependencies into shared classes in order to ensure that Spark and Flink backends can be used without dependency on the other. For example, there are (1) references to Flink in runtime/controlprogram/Program, and (2) references to the SparkExecutionContext in Flink execution modes. Could you please systematically go over shared classes and double check for isolation?

3) Bufferpool integration: I agree that the duplication of RDDObject and DataSetObject creates unnecessary redundancy in a core place like our bufferpool (CacheableData and ExecutionContext). Let's abstract this to something like DistDataObject with two implementations RDDObject and DataSetObject. Just let me know, I'd be happy to prepare this for you guys.

4) Broadcast memory budget: Currently, the broadcast memory budget is obtained from the SparkExecutionContext. It would be good to automatically obtain this size (e.g., size for user objects) to remove the dependency and because it is really important for operator selection.

5) Checkpointing: I see a CheckpointFLInstruction which always does a pass-through. Let's remove this instruction (until Flink supports distributed caching) and simply do not apply the rewrites for injecting these checkpoints (RewriteInjectSparkLoopCheckpointing, RewriteInjectSparkPReadCheckpointing).  

6) Instructions w/ broadcasts: There seem to be some inconsistencies wrt when and how we broadcast data (e.g., join vs join w/ hint vs withBroadcastSet). I understand that Flink offers optimization capabilities in that regard. However, from a SystemML perspective I would recommend to stick to physical operator semantics (e.g., MAPMM with broadcast, CPMM/RMM with join). If experiments show that Flink actually does better than our operator selection, we could simply compile earlier (for smaller data sizes) CPMM/RMM. Btw, is there a way to pin the broadcast in distributed memory and reuse it across multiple invocations? 

7) Advanced operations: You already added compiler support for advanced operations like weighted squared loss and cumulative aggregates. Let's put these aside for now and get a narrow prototype running well first before we broaden the scope.

8) Tests: It would be good if we could add a few tests for flink mapmm and tsmm to ensure they are producing correct results as this is the precondition for any experiments. Please have a look into FullMatrixMultiplicationTransposeSelfTest and FullDistributedMatrixMultiplicationTest.

9) Exception handling: There are a couple of instances where exceptions are simply put to stderr. Could you please double check that all caught exceptions are rethrown in order to simplify debugging. Also, please replace the assertions for dimensions mismatch checks with exceptions as these checks need to happen even if assertions are disabled (by default).

10) Formatting: Well, we don't have a style guide defined yet but the project-wide convention is to use tabs instead of spaces (e.g., issues in DMLScript). Furthermore, you've also done some code cleanups of formatting existing code. Could we separate these changes out of this PR to simplify the review? Feel free to submit them as an individual PR though.  

Finally, as a next step after this PR I would recommend to extend the scenario to LinearRegCG.dml as an iterative algorithm with similar core operations. I would find an investigation of Flink's iteration features very interesting. One direction could be to automatically compile this iteration construct for while loops via rewrites.
4) Please also consider to implement it as matrix to string cast (with special handling of 1x1 matrices) which would resolve the previously discussed issue of print("result = "+X[1,1]) as well.

LGTM - thanks @gweidner 

With regard to circular references, I would recommend to use a similar approach as IPA and the parfor optimizer, i.e., a simple function/namespace stack that is carried along while parsing.

Hi Matthias,

thanks a lot for the extensive review! This is a great help for us and we'll get going on the suggestions right away.
ad 3) I would recommend to define a maxrow/col threshold (let's say 1k) - if the matrix is larger, we have to generate indexing operations.
Merged.  Thanks, @gweidner!

@nakul02  
maxRow/maxCol is not range but more like a threshold as @mboehm7 said. We has default value but user can set it when necessary.
dense means "dense matrix", if it's `false`, means "sparse matrix" here we may want print as:
i, j, value
LGTM
This is a great start .. thanks @FelixNeutatz @fschueler @akunft

Printing large dense matrices will be too overwhelming. Users will always use range indexing to display parts of a large matrix, or other ops such as head, tail, firstCols, lastCols, etc. If users print "too much", then there should be some built-in guards to avoid thrashing. This is quite common across systems.
Printing large sparse matrices, i.e. ultra sparse matrices, in <i, j, v> format will be helpful if you don't know the range of where the values are. Yes, there are ways to find out, however having these convenience built-in capabilities will definitely improve the user experience.
Btw, will that apply to frames as well?
@bertholdreinwald - For this PR, I am dealing with matrices only. I'd suggest we deal with frames in a separate JIRA.

I like the idea of toString() method that Matthias suggested and this method can be extended to Frames later:

``` python
X = rand(rows=10000, cols=10000, min=0, max=4, pdf="uniform", sparsity=0.2)
print(toString(X, format="csv", rows=1000, cols=10))
```

Internally, toString() method could have built-in guards that Berthold is suggesting. I like Matthias's idea of implicitly introducing indexing op, which performs following logic (but at hop level):

``` python
rlen = nrow(X)
if(nrow(X) > rowThreshold) {
   rlen = rowThreshold
}
clen = ncol(X)
if(ncol(X) > colThreshold) {
   clen = colThreshold
}
print(toString(X[1:rlen, 1:clen], ...))
```

The next question is why not do implicit conversion instead of toString() method. I like implicit conversion iff we can handle following DML code:

``` python
y = " " + X
X1 = y * X
```

Also, I would like to point out that at language level we have a string representation of matrix, i.e. `matrix("1 2 3 4", rows=2 ,cols=2)`. By having a pretty printing builtin function like toString(), we don't have to worry about incorrect implicit conversions. 

Though I don't have a strong opinion about format type, I would suggest sticking to format that we expose in read/write methods (i.e. "csv" for dense and "text" for sparse) rather than call then as dense or sparse OR we can add the new pretty printed matrix format into read/write as well.
Looks good to me.
Let's deal with the code formatting later. This is ready to merge after https://github.com/apache/incubator-systemml/pull/116 is merged.
Test this Jenkins.

https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/271/
There is build status here. It pass

@Wenpei Sorry, to add one more task ... Can you please add following logic to your PR ?

if the user has not provided DML path to LogisticRegression (for example: setDMLScriptPath(....)), then use https://github.com/apache/incubator-systemml/blob/master/src/main/scala/org/apache/sysml/api/ml/scala/ScriptsUtils.scala#L38 ... else use the user provided one.

Here is an example:

``` python
if(no path provided by user)
   ml.executeScript(ScriptsUtils.getDMLScript("GLM-predict"),paramsMap)
else
   ml.execute(ScriptsUtils.resolvePath(LogisticRegressionModel.scriptPath),paramsMap)
```

This will avoid any hassle of requiring environment variables.

@niketanpansare I do some check in ScriptsUtils to return full string of file but not a path.
Please help to review.

Looks good to me.

@dusenberrymw @deroneriksson Please merge this PR. Thanks :)
I'll merge. Thank you @Wenpei
thanks @deroneriksson
Closing this PR.

Just FYI, this can be automatically closed by appending `Closses #117.` to the end of a commit message.  This nice side-effect is that it also links (clickable link) the commit to this PR and the discussion on it.

@Wenpei Added MLPipeline test for the wrappers. The test ran successfully on my laptop. Please comment if you have any concerns.

@dusenberrymw @deroneriksson Please merge if @Wenpei is OK with it.
Is this different from #117?
@dusenberrymw No, the main difference is that in this PR, I cleaned up the formatting issue and resolved conflicts.

Based on the discussion here, offline discussion with @niketanpansare and some thought, IMHO, here are a two of ways of printing matrices:

### 1. Introduce DML functions - `as.string, castAsString`

```
X = rand(rows=1000, cols=1000, min=0, max=4, pdf="uniform", sparsity=0.2)
Z = as.string(X[1:10,1:10])
print(Z)
```

The `as.string` can have additional arguments that @Wenpei suggested (i.e. maxRows, maxCols, dense & decimel with default values for each)

```
Y = as.string(X, maxRows=10, maxCols=20, decimel=4)
print("The matrix is " + Y)
```

This method has the problem of explicitly converting matrices to strings before passing them to the print statement.
Since the entire system assumes that any binary operation with a matrix yields a matrix, checks for that would not have to be modified throughout the system.
Also `as.string` would extend to frames and other data structures as they come along.

### 2. Support it directly from the print statement (as is done in this PR)

This code would work directly because the builtin print function would know how to handle matrices.

```
X = rand(rows=1000, cols=1000, min=0, max=4, pdf="uniform", sparsity=0.2)
Z = X[1:10,1:10]
print(Z)
```

Additional arguments can be passed to the print statement like so

```
print (Z, maxRows=10, maxCols=5, dense=true)
```

This method would have the problem of changing the underlying systems assumption that any binary operation with a matrix yields a matrix. 
The advantage is that it would "feel" more natural.

Thoughts?

from my side a +1 for option one - this allows much more flexibility. 

However, in terms of language-level integration, we need to think about better alternatives because as.logical / as.integer / as.double and the proposed as.string are pure value-type casts whereas the proposed functionality covers both value-type and data-type cast, i.e., double - matrix into string - scalar. Also, please under no circumstance introduce anything like castAsString - the existing castAsScalar is just kept for historic reasons (its introduction was a mistake but when we replaced it with as.scalar we had to keep it for backwards compatibility because it was already used by external users).

The new code tracks imported scripts in a static variable and skips/defers building the corresponding DMLProgram for redundant/circular reference.  A static variable was used to facilitate access in exitImportStatement across multiple DMLSyntacticValidator's which get instantiated during processing.
Note importing the same script under different namespace is allowed (namespace conflicts to be addressed in SYSTEMML-631).

All tests passed in [OnDemand build 149](https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-OnDemand/149/).

one more note: although the scalar-string cast is a much better solution in terms of runtime flexibility - for convenience you might want to automatically compile it whenever somebody feeds a matrix directly into a print.
LGTM.

thanks @GrapeBaBa - since you explicitly interrupt the thread, could you please also add the related  handling of InterruptedException (e.g., something like LOG.warn("Status reporter interrupted with stop="+_stop)
LGTM - thanks @deroneriksson
it would be great if we could also automatically compare the results - maybe against a manually evaluated ground truth.
@mboehm7 Done.

thanks @gweidner that looks already pretty good - just two comments.

1) Thread-local state: could you please change the global state (static map) to thread-local state management in order to prevent side-effects between concurrent scripts parsing in a shared JVM process. The scenario is JMLC scoring (one prepared script per core) in a shared Spark executor process.  
2) Consistency function keys: Internally (independent of the language facet), we try to always use DMLProgram.constructFunctionKey() for building fully qualified function names. It would be good to reuse that in order to avoid surprises for devs expecting a certain schema.
LGTM

that's a good start @asurve - couple of comments:

1) Block merge: It would be good to implement the frame block merge via copy, not cell access for performance (intrinsics) and robustness (with regards to different schemas).

2) Convert FrameBlockToIJVLines: You don't need a lazy iterator here as the input is bounded to one block. Please simplify by simply adding all cells to to an ArrayList - this might even solve you occasional serialization issues.

3) FrameConverterUtils: Please order the actual converter methods to the top (and internal functions to the bottom) and make sure that overloaded methods call each other for consitency (e.g., textCellToBinaryBlock and textCellToBinaryBlockLongIndex).

4) FrameBinaryBlockToTextCellConverter: This converter does not implement setBlockSize - either implement or remove it.

5) Tests: Given 3, you don't need separate tests for TXTCELL2BIN and TXTCELL2BIN_LONGIDX - please remove one of them.

6) Code style: Please use x++ instead of ++x for generic increments where you do not rely on a pre-increment. Also please simplify boolean assignments e.g., 'bNextCellExists = (nextRow != _block.getNumRows())'. Finally, remove unnecessary casts (e.g., in fromIndexedFrameBlock).

+1 for first option. Please make sure that formatting options, e.g. separator, EoL, can be provided for convenient import into Excel, etc. A one-dimensional sequence of numbers w/o formatting may not be helpful.

Ethan, thank you for preparing this section under Troubleshooting guide.
I am, however, not sure about the need for this -- especially because these are Hadoop settings that are relevant for any application running on Hadoop. We are also not providing any recommended settings specific to SystemML -- for example, we recommend three times the HDFS block size for `mapreduce.task.io.sort.mb` based on the way SystemML operates. In contrast, we are not providing any SystemML-specific recommended settings here.

I would like to see what others think about it.

I assume you want to export only the accuracy number so that the exported file can be easily consumed by other softwares. 

LGTM.
I am in favor of accepting this PR. @ethanyxu is running SystemML on a large dataset on a large Hadoop cluster. Another user in a similar situation may find this information helpful.

If accepted, my one request would be to update the absolute link to `http://apache.github.io/incubator-systemml/hadoop-batch-mode.html` to a relative link `[Invoking SystemML in Hadoop Batch Mode](hadoop-batch-mode.html)`

I too am in favor of adding this, as it represents a simple solution to a particular Hadoop issue that has presented itself in the course of running SystemML on a real problem.

@ethanyxu Thanks for continuing to bring to our attention the various issues and scenarios that you have encountered.

Let's please keep this as simple as possible at the language level, and not _force_ usage in DML of anything like `as.string(...)` with a multitude of parameters just for simply printing a matrix (which will just be used for small scale data exploration and algorithm writing/debugging).  It's already annoying enough for users to have to convert a 1x1 matrix `X` to a scalar with `as.scalar(X)` every time we want to print it or assign it to a scalar variable (i.e. when performing a full right index `X[1,5]`).  That being said, we can definitely use the first option internally for cleanliness within the compiler.

Couple of comments:
1. Can you include at least first few lines from the stack trace insteadof just `java.lang.OutOfMemoryError`, so that the cause of such an error is more explicit.
2. Change the wording `per-task basis` -- the word 'task' can be misled to mean individual map reduce tasks.
3. How do the Hadoop configuration parameters specified in `SystemML-config.xml` are propagated to individual MR jobs that are created?

Thank you @mboehm7 for your time and always helpful comments.  I've incorporated ThreadLocal for the static map in CommonSyntacticValidator and constructFunctionKey for the map's keys in DML/PyDMLSyntacticValidator.  I patterned ThreadLocal changes after similar ThreadLocal usage in hops Recompiler but please let me know if I've misinterpreted anything.

Prior to pushing this commit of 3 files I rebased and pushed this branch to merge in latest parser updates from master.  [PR build 287](https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/287/) in progress for commits containing ThreadLocal.
@Wenpei Thank you. I will merge.
@mboehm7 @niketanpansare Should I merge this PR or hold off for now?
LGTM - let's just ensure that over time we extend this to actual tests for correctness.
Thank you @mboehm7 and @niketanpansare . I'll merge.
Sorry for late reply, I agree with Matthias. We need to check for ground truth. Thanks @deroneriksson.

Could we have both 1 (with no options) and 2?
print(m) simply prints out something (ANYTHING besides throwing an error), and if the user decides this is not sufficient, the user can do a print(as.string(m, maxRows=10, maxCols=20, decimal=4)) to specify some specifics?
@niketanpansare Could you file a JIRA for the ground truth check?
Thank you @GrapeBaBa . I will merge.
LGTM - thanks @gweidner

Done. 

@Wenpei Do you want to take a look at https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SYSTEMML-646 ?

Also, we still need to adjust the package for these tests to place them in a test package, and then create a new test suite so that they will be run with Maven. There's already a JIRA issue tracking this with more details.
Thank you @gweidner . I will merge.
Thanks Glenn for this great contribution! I'll close the JIRA since Apache JIRA is on 'lockdown' mode today.
Thank you @niketanpansare
Thanks, @gweidner!

LGTM - Just one minor fix before you push: please remove the unnecessary list-arrary-list conversion in ConvertFrameBlockToIJVLines (Arrays.asList(cells.toArray())). Also for the future, please make sure not to use scala.actors.threadpool.Arrays but java.util.Arrays (I know it gets auto-resolved to the scala version since SystemML has been made a mixed scala/java project).
I'm also in favor of extending our trouble shooting guide as we go, even if these issues are not always related to SystemML core. Thanks @ethanyxu
@niketanpansare I will take a look for 646
Thanks

Thanks @nishi-t . Wrt changing names of arguments, please be aware that this will create an incompatibility if somebody implemented an application using the old names. Hence, this should be carefully introduced and well documented for app developers to be aware of. How many names would you have to change?

@nishi-t Thanks for updating this!  Can you increase the number of iterations to 20 instead of 10 though?  In specific cases, such as the k-means script, we've had issues when the number of iterations is below 20.
Thanks @dusenberrymw . Addressed your comment in the commit 03529f3

I've implemented an initial version of `as.string`. It supports the following named arguments: | Argument | Description | Default | | --- | --- | --- | | "rows" | Maximum number of rows to print | 100 | | "cols" | Maximum number of columns to print | 100 | | "decimal" | Number after decimal to print, 0 padded | 3 | | "sparse" | Whether to print in **sparse** format, which is Row Index, Col Index, Value | FALSE | | "separator" | Separator String between elements in a row or between the three columns in sparse Format | " " | | "lineseparator" | Separator String between rows or between each line in sparse format | "\n" | Here are some examples in use: Program: ``` X = rand(rows=10, cols=10, min=0, max=4, pdf="uniform", sparsity=0.2) print ("matrix \n" + as.string(X)) ``` Program: ``` X = rand(rows=10, cols=10, min=0, max=4, pdf="uniform", sparsity=0.2) x1 = as.string(X, decimal=5) print ("matrix \n" + x1 ) ``` Program: ``` X = rand(rows=10, cols=10, min=0, max=4, pdf="uniform", sparsity=0.2) x1 = as.string(X, rows=5, cols=5) print ("matrix \n" + x1) ``` Program: ``` X = rand(rows=10, cols=10, min=0, max=4, pdf="uniform", sparsity=0.2) x1 = as.string(X, sparse=TRUE, rows=5, cols=10) print ("matrix \n" + x1) ``` Program: ``` X = rand(rows=10, cols=10, min=0, max=4, pdf="uniform", sparsity=0.2) x1 = as.string(X, separator=" | ") print ("matrix \n" + x1) ``` Program: ``` X = rand(rows=10, cols=10, min=0, max=4, pdf="uniform", sparsity=0.2) x1 = as.string(X, lineseparator=" | ", rows=4, cols=4) print ("matrix \n" + x1) ```
This is great!

@nakul02 I also really like your idea of the automatic invocation of as.string in a print call on a matrix as a separate PR. That way users have both 1) ease-of-use (print(m)) and 2) flexibility (print(as.string(m,...))).
In a follow-up PR (or this one) we should also replace all uses of `castAsScalar(...)` with `as.scalar(...)` in any of our DML/PyDML files.
Sounds good. Already created https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SYSTEMML-647 to address this. Should just be a couple big find/replaces. (DML with as.scalar(), PYDML with scalar())
@nakul02 LGTM

looks good. One last thought looking at your green on black MVS terminal output (saying that, does that date me), I couldn't help but count the rows and columns for identification. Would it be useful to include row# and col# to the output?, i.e.

```
0   1   2
```

0: 20 21 22 
1: 10 32 33
2: 12 33 99

thanks @deroneriksson for debugging this issue. However, I would strongly recommend not to create these additional special cases in DAG (which would lead to different conditions firing for normal transient reads and transient reads introduced by jmlc/mlcontext). Couldn't we instead modify RewriteRemovePersistentReadWrite and clear the filename in case of scalars?

@bertholdreinwald - I like the green on black, easy on the eyes :)

Just as a thought, if you intend on copy-pasting this into excel or another program, the prepended row numbers would be a hindrance and excel would provide that info anyways. But i leave the decision up to you. We could also make the output fancier by taking in more named parameters.

Another thing you might have noticed is that I begin row and column numbering from 0.
This may not be what a DML user is expecting since programmatically, they begin numbering from 1.
I can, and will fix this before the final commit. 
Also each row ends with the separator string. Maybe I should change this, I probably will, unless you or someone else thinks its not a good idea.

thanks @deroneriksson - couple of comments

1) Please move the warnings after the parse call into the parse method (potentially make parse a wrapper that calls some internalParse of the subclasses). It would be very usefull to keep
the parser invocation a single call that handles everything internally as it is called multiple times.
2) Always use logging for these warnings. The only write to stdout in SystemML should come from print. In the past we had severe issues where SystemML (running in a fenced process)
eventually blocked because the stdout queue filled up. Btw, that's why we have a flag to disable any prints (_suppressPrint2Stdout).
3) What is the rational behind renaming the casting operations?
4) Conditional validate: could we please keep the conditional flag for raiseValidateError to make clear
when warnings instead of errors are raised (if validate of conditional control flow where we don't know if this is ever gonna be executed, which simplifies for example the handling of conditional inputs; otherwise we would need to always provide valid filenames there).

it's a good start @nakul02 but I would recommend a rework of the actual builtin function and it's implementation:

1) Builtin function: As mentioned before as.string will later be used as a cast of value types e.g., for scalars/frames (no change of the data type!). Could you please find another builtin name that conveys the meaning better. How about R's cat or toString (please have a look at the docs)? We should only introduce custom functions if there is a real good argument for it. Also, in relation to existing functions like read, write and transformmeta it would be good to use 'sep' instead of 'separator'.

2) ExecType selection: Please fix the execution type selection (independent of memory, see transformmeta). Right now the compilation would crash for large matrices or in forced exec type hadoop/spark. 

3) String conversion: Please move the print out of core data structures like MatrixBlock, SparseBlock and all its implementations. This functionality is not performance critical
and should be implemented against basic sparse iterators or get. Maybe you can integrate it into DataConverter (there you will find also examples how to use the generic internal apis).

thanks @niketanpansare - you certainly put a lot of effort in here. Could we please separate those PRs though? It would be great to get the new dml builtin functions in first, with tests but without new dependencies and without reuse of allocated dense arrays and other custom extensions (that do not generalize to all scenarios yet). We could discuss the other extensions as soon as we're comfortable with the baseline builtin functions.
